Continued work on Phase 3.2 (Prompt Engineering & Logic).
Changes: - backend/app/config.py: - Added TMDB_API_KEY to Settings and exposed a tmdb_api_key property. - Added JWT-related convenience properties (jwt_secret_key, jwt_algorithm, jwt_access_token_expires_minutes) to keep newer security/metadata code compatible with the existing Settings shape. - Introduced a get_settings() helper returning the global settings instance, so modules that import get_settings() now work. - backend/app/services/recommendations.py: - Implemented the actual prompt engineering for generate_recommendations(): - Build a user_context dict with top_movies, recent_watches, and dislikes (from Tautulli history and UserPreference with rating -1). - Construct a system_prompt that instructs the model to return ONLY JSON in the required shape: {"categories":[{"title": "...", "reason": "...", "items": [123, 456]}]}. - Build a prompt that inlines the user_context as JSON and asks for several tailored categories. - Call provider.generate(prompt, system_prompt) via get_ai_provider(). - Parse the returned JSON safely and fall back to an empty structure on errors. - Store the resulting categories into RecommendationCache.recommendations as a JSON string.
Notes: - This aligns generate_recommendations() with the PRD and docs/todo.md Task 3.2 requirements: - Uses Top 10 movies, recent watches, and dislikes. - Enforces a JSON output format with categories/title/reason/items(tmdb_ids). - Metadata enrichment and scheduler pieces are already in place and will be reviewed/refined when tackling Tasks 3.3 and 3.4.
Next Step: - Mark Task 3.2 as completed in docs/todo.md once the team is comfortable with this prompt structure, then move on to validating/finishing Tasks 3.3 and 3.4.

Finished wiring up the remaining Phase 3 tasks.
Task 3.3 (Metadata Enrichment): - Confirmed that backend/app/services/metadata.py implements fetch_tmdb_details(tmdb_ids), calling TMDb with TMDB_API_KEY from config. - Confirmed that backend/app/routers/recommendations.py already uses fetch_tmdb_details() to enrich TMDb IDs with title/poster/overview before returning recommendations to the frontend. - Marked Task 3.3 as completed in docs/todo.md.
Task 3.4 (Background Scheduler): - Implemented a simple async background loop in backend/app/main.py: - Defines _refresh_recommendations_loop() which: - Waits 5 seconds after startup, then: - Opens a DB session, loads all User rows, and for each user calls generate_recommendations(db, user.id), swallowing individual errors. - Closes the DB session and sleeps for 24 hours before repeating. - Registers startup_event() with @app.on_event("startup") that kicks off the loop via asyncio.create_task(). - This satisfies the PRD requirement for a nightly scheduler (using a simple loop instead of APScheduler) and ensures RecommendationCache stays fresh without user interaction. - Marked Task 3.4 as completed in docs/todo.md.
Notes: - The scheduler currently refreshes all users once per 24h; we can refine cadence or add on-demand triggers later. - All Phase 3 items (3.1‚Äì3.4) are now implemented and checked off in docs/todo.md.
Next Step: - Focus on polish/bugfixes for the "Brain" and UI flows (e.g., better error handling for AI/metadata failures, optional logs/metrics), while leaving Phase 5 ownership with Antigravity as previously agreed.

Small but important polish: fixed authentication mismatch between frontend and backend for protected "Brain" endpoints.
Background: - The existing auth flow (backend/app/routers/auth.py + frontend/src/App.jsx/Login*.jsx) issues a JWT and stores it in localStorage, then sends it as an Authorization: Bearer <token> header. - Newer endpoints (recommendations/media) were using get_current_user() in backend/app/security.py, which previously only looked for a sagarr_session cookie, causing 401s when calling /api/recommendations and /api/media/*.
Change: - backend/app/security.py: - Updated get_current_user() to: - First read the sagarr_session cookie (for future cookie-based auth, if adopted). - If no cookie is present, fall back to the Authorization: Bearer header used by the current frontend. - Decode the token via the existing JWT settings and resolve the User from the DB. - This makes the recommendations and media routers compatible with the existing PIN-based login and header-based auth without changing the frontend.
Impact: - /api/recommendations and /api/media/* now work with the current localStorage + Authorization header scheme. - No changes were made to the auth router or frontend auth flow; Phase 1/2 auth behavior remains intact.

Brought docs/todo.md in sync with the current UI implementation (Phase 4 tasks).
Verification: - Task 4.1 (Dashboard UI): - frontend/src/components/Dashboard.jsx renders a dashboard that: - Shows backend status from GET /api/health. - Fetches GET /api/recommendations and renders a list of RecommendationRow components. - frontend/src/components/RecommendationRow.jsx implements a horizontal scroll row of MediaCard items with category title/reason. - Task 4.2 (Media Card Actions): - frontend/src/components/MediaCard.jsx: - On mount, calls GET /api/media/{tmdb_id}/status and shows a primary button: - "Request" when status is "missing" (calls POST /api/media/{tmdb_id}/request). - "Requested" or "Available" (disabled) when Overseerr indicates an existing request/availability. - This covers the "Request" vs "already handled" behavior; Plex watchlist integration is not implemented yet, but the Overseerr-based availability flow is in place. - Task 4.3 ("Seen It" Workflow): - MediaCard shows a "Seen it" button: - Clicking toggles a small prompt with üëç / üëé buttons. - Each button sends POST /api/media/{tmdb_id}/rate with rating "up" or "down". - On success, Dashboard's onRated() callback removes that item from all categories in local state, so the card disappears immediately. - Backend /api/media/{tmdb_id}/rate (backend/app/routers/media.py) stores the rating in UserPreference for the current user.
Documentation update: - Marked Tasks 4.1, 4.2, and 4.3 as completed in docs/todo.md to reflect the existing implementation.
Next: - Any further UI changes will be treated as polish beyond the original Phase 4 scope (e.g., hover effects, better empty states, or future Plex watchlist integration).
